stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 11th course, an oil rig level, focusing on a mission where Mario breaks a glass pane carried by Koopas. This involved faking physics for the shattering effect, adding dialogue, and programming the Koopas' reactions. He also cut a separate, unintuitive mission objective and began modeling and designing a new Wiggler character to act as a mission overseer, balancing visual ideas against the N64's polygon budget.

development_findings.summary: To create a glass-shattering effect, Kaze opted to hard-code a simple animation of two large pieces falling away, deciding it was more efficient than creating a real physics simulation or managing many small object pieces.
development_findings.quote: we're just gonna fake it so we don't actually have to write a physics simulation.

development_findings.summary: A planned mission objective was cut because Kaze felt it was unintuitive and the comedic payoff was not worth the potential player frustration.
development_findings.quote: This is bad because it's just so cryptic to just kick over the random oil barrel. Who would think to do that?

development_findings.summary: Kaze's development philosophy has evolved; he now believes in dedicating at least 20% of project time to design, a significant shift from his earlier 'unfiltered' approach on projects like 'Last Impact'.
development_findings.quote: when I made last impact i spent like maybe... 5% of the time designing and like 95% of the time working but i should have been spending at least 20% of the time designing.

development_findings.summary: The design of a new Wiggler character was directly constrained by the N64's polygon budget, forcing Kaze to abandon a comedic idea of putting hard hats on each body segment to save triangles.
development_findings.quote: a thousand triangles is too much. Can't waste my polygon budget like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes that simply because a feature or design choice existed in the original Super Mario 64, it is not a valid justification for including it in a new project.
development_findings.quote: I think Mario 64 does it is a bad excuse overall. Just because Mario 64 does so many stupid things.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided to add a secret, non-required Wing Cap to the level for fun, planning to use simple invisible walls to prevent players from flying out of bounds.
Kaze implemented an anti-save-state feature in his side project 'Only Up 64' by detecting when the EPROM memory desynchronizes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze passionately argues that a 'controller plus mouse' setup is the optimal input method for genres like shooters, combining the aiming precision of a mouse with the nuanced analog movement of a joystick.
context_findings.quote: controller plus mouse is the future... it's the best for sure.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a strong dislike for 2D platformers, stating he finds them mechanically archaic. He cited quitting Hollow Knight immediately upon discovering its analog stick controls emulated an 8-way d-pad.
context_findings.quote: I watched the intro cutscene and then I touched the control stick and I instantly stopped playing the game because the control stick was an emulated d-pad... Why would I want to play a game on a fucking d-pad? Are we in 1990?

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about why he no longer shaves his head, explaining that in Germany, a bald head can carry a negative political stigma.
context_findings.quote: I did that once and everyone thought I was being a Nazi because I was bald. And usually when you're bald in German, people think you're being a Nazi.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works remotely as a programmer for Gears for Breakfast, the studio behind 'A Hat in Time'. He describes the job as 'super chill' but is mindful of his NDA.
Kaze revealed he created a side project, 'Only Up 64,' primarily to win prize money from a 'troll hack competition'.
context_findings.quote: it's not really that much of a troll hack but like free money you know if you submit to the troll like competition someone was gonna just give you money

biobak.summary: Biobak was not present, but Kaze jokingly suggested making an Andrew Tate theme song the 'Biobak theme song' to troll him, indicating a playful team dynamic.
biobak.quote: How come Biobak's not here? This would be like his theme song dude what if we just start calling this the Biobak theme song.

badub.summary: Badub has created a work-in-progress soundtrack for the oil rig level, which Kaze feels has 'pretty good ideas' but may need atmosphere adjustments.
Badub provided a new version of a Yoshi's Island night theme, which Kaze played on stream and reacted to positively.

zeina.summary: Zeina is handling animations for characters like the baby penguins and the Koopas carrying glass. She clarified her role extends to helping with anything Kaze needs for the project.
zeina.quote: I'm just helping out with animations. And anything else that he needs.

zeina.summary: Zeina actively collaborates on 3D models during the stream, identifying a hole in the penguin model's mesh that needed to be fixed.
zeina.quote: He just has a hole in the top of his head, of his neck.

zeina.summary: Zeina expressed that the newly created Wiggler character will be extremely challenging to animate, even more so than the Bowser model.
zeina.quote: He's gonna be the most difficult one to animate yet. I thought Bowser was difficult enough, this is gonna be even worse.

key_stories.title: Faking the Physics of Shattering Glass
key_stories.summary: When faced with creating a breakable glass pane, Kaze explored several options. He ultimately rejected complex solutions like particle systems or numerous pre-shattered pieces due to the high workload, instead opting to 'fake' the physics with a simple, hard-coded animation.
key_stories.challenge: To create a satisfying effect for a glass pane shattering on the N64 without a prohibitive amount of modeling or complex physics programming.
key_stories.process: Kaze considered and rejected using many small models (due to the 'physical amount of work') and 2D particles (believing they don't fit sharp glass). He settled on modeling two large, pre-broken halves and then writing hard-coded C code to animate them falling and spinning away.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a simple, two-piece split that was convincing enough for the game. This demonstrates his pragmatic approach, prioritizing efficiency and 'good enough' results over technically complex simulations.
key_stories.key_quote: we're just gonna fake it so we don't actually have to write a physics simulation.

key_stories.title: The Wiggler's Polygon Budget
key_stories.summary: After scrapping a mission idea, Kaze decided to create a new Wiggler character to act as an overseer. His initial design ideas, which included a hard hat for each body segment, quickly exceeded the N64's polygon budget, forcing him to make practical design compromises.
key_stories.challenge: To design a unique, themed Wiggler character while staying within the strict technical limitations of the N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze modeled a Wiggler and gave it worker's boots and a hard hat. A comedic idea to add tiny hats to each body segment was implemented, but Kaze discovered the polygon count was too high (nearly 1000 triangles). He then systematically reduced the poly count by removing internal faces from the helmets and abandoning the multiple-hat idea.
key_stories.outcome: The final Wiggler design was simplified to meet technical constraints, with just one hat instead of one on each segment. This incident is a clear example of how N64 limitations directly shape the game's art and design.
key_stories.key_quote: God, he's like a thousand triangles now though... a thousand triangles is too much. Can't waste my polygon budget like that.

key_stories.title: Cutting the Cryptic Content
key_stories.summary: The oil rig level was planned to have five 'troll' objectives, but Kaze decided to cut one involving an oil barrel. He reasoned that the solution was unintuitive and the comedic payoff wasn't worth the potential player confusion, showing his focus on clear design.
key_stories.challenge: One of the five planned mission objectives felt unintuitive and not fun enough to justify its inclusion.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed the plan to have the player kick an oil barrel to make a worker slip. He concluded that players wouldn't naturally think to do this. He briefly considered adding more visual cues but ultimately decided the entire concept was flawed and not worth the effort.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze removed the objective, reducing the mission from five 'trolls' to four. He then created the Wiggler overseer concept to tie the remaining objectives together, highlighting his willingness to cut content that doesn't meet his design standards for clarity and fun.
key_stories.key_quote: I think kicking the oil barrel is not intuitive and also that's not very funny. So I'm not really a fan of that.
